awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Rapid Characterization of Wood-based Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will enable the wood industry to certify materials along its entire supply chain, achieving reproducibility and reducing delays in the movement of goods, and supporting the economic competitiveness of American wood companies. The technology being developed by this project entails rapid and accurate wood species identification, which will bring transparency to the wood industry, helping to enable proper forest management that follows social, economic, and government standards. The technology will also promote quality control of products and characterization of residues leftover from wood processing, which in turn would facilitate their recovery and reutilization. By allowing manufacturers to achieve reproducibility in composite material manufacturing, the technology will encourage the recycling of wood waste and byproducts, supporting efforts to increase the sustainability and reduce the environmental impact of the wood industry. Lastly, this technology will empower organizations combating illegal logging by providing a new and powerful forensic tool, thus addressing deforestation and forest depletion with significant economic, societal, and ecological benefits.

  
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project is applying state-of-the-art chemical analysis methods to develop a novel wood identification technology capable of determining with accuracy the species, age, and geographical origin of uniform or composite products. With the increase in demand for transparency in the wood industry and more stringent regulations comes a demand for new technologies that support compliance. Despite being a critical step in this process, current methods for species identification are time consuming, require highly specialized training, and provide little information on age and origin. By combining a highly sensitive type of spectroscopy with advanced statistical approaches (i.e., machine learning), this project is developing a method that can reliably identify chemical fingerprints that inform about wood species, age, and origin when compared against a database. This Phase I project will develop and demonstrate this approach when applied to U.S. woods, including the creation of a wood species database, with these key objectives: 1) analyze domestic woods to develop statistical methods to identify the species; 2) test the method’s ability identify species within composite materials; 3) test the method’s ability to identify the geographical origin of samples; and 4) test the method’s ability to determine wood age.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
In this NSF Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project, Sangali developed a wood identification technology for both the private and public sectors of the lumber supply chain. It couples a material's species-specific chemical fingerprint, obtained using mass spectrometry, with machine learning processing to provide precise, fast, affordable and high-throughput analysis of wood with a minimal amount of wood material. Samples can be analyzed in their native form. The approach furnishes not only genus- and species-level information of wood or materials fashioned from wood, but also the geographic origin of the wood. In addition, it can be used to determine the species constituents of wood composite materials.

            With the increasing demand for supply chain transparency in the wood industry and the imposition of strict government regulations, there is a growing need for tracking and tracing technology to promote and ensure compliance, which Sangali can provide. Current wood identification technology methods are time consuming, require specialized training and provide little information on wood origin or the species constituents of composite mixture materials. Sangali has developed a comprehensive database of domestic North American wood species and a machine learning processing approach that enables facile identification of: (1) the genus and species of wood and products fashioned from it; (2) the genus and species represented within composite materials; and (3) the geographic origin of samples.

            Sangali's developed wood identification system has a number of broader impacts. It supports the nation's economic competitiveness by allowing those in the wood industry to certify wood materials along the supply chain and achieve reproducibility while also reducing delays in the movement of goods. Through the demonstration of operational transparency, public confidence in the wood industry's support for forest management that follows social, economic and government standards will improve. Additionally, the technology's fast and accurate identification will promote quality control of products for the benefit of consumers. This will in turn facilitate appropriate recovery, waste reduction and responsible recycling of wood residues generated during the processing of logs, or in the waste produced from sawmills, carpenters' workshops, furniture factories and offcuts from building sites (i.e., scaffolding planks, struts). Finally, this technology can empower organizations with the mission of combatting illegal logging (both federal and private) by providing an accurate and affordable forensic tool for wood identification, thereby providing economic, societal and environmental stewardship benefits.

 


Last Modified: 02/13/2025
Modified by: Allix Coon
